item.title: UK Visa Scams Squeeze Millions From Would-Be Care Workers
item.description: Recent changes to immigration policy won’t do anything for people who’ve been exploited while seeking jobs in the UK. But they may worsen the care-worker shortage.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White

media:content.media:description: Mr. Brown (left), a self-described “scammer hunter,” and his de facto bodyguard Sting.

item.title: Poland’s Presidential Vote Puts Tusk’s Reform Agenda at Stake
item.description: Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk’s push to undo eight years of populist rule faces a reckoning just as other parts of Europe struggle to contain rising support for more conservative, nationalist forces.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Ojewska

media:content.media:description: Donald Tusk Photographer: Damian Lemanski/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Tax Cuts Rejected by House Panel as GOP Hardliners Dig In
item.description: A key House committee on Friday failed to advance House Republicans’ massive tax-and-spending bill after hard-line conservatives bucked President Donald Trump and blocked the bill over cost concerns.
item.dc:creator: Emily Birnbaum, Jarrell Dillard, Tyler Kendall

media:content.media:description: UNITED STATES - MAY 16: Rep. Chip Roy, R-Texas, arrives for the House Budget Committee markup of the reconciliation bill in the Cannon House Office Building on Friday, May 16, 2025. (Bill Clark/CQ-Roll Call, Inc via Getty Images)

item.title: Slovenia Calls on NATO to Expand Its Defense Spending Definition
item.description: Slovenia and several NATO member states are seeking ways to expand the definition of defense spending as they attempt to meet US calls to allocate more funds on security, the nation’s prime minister said.
item.dc:creator: Jan Bratanic

media:content.media:description: Robert Golob, Slovenia's prime minister, speaks to members of the media during the NATO Summit in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, July 10, 2024. President Joe Biden and NATO's 31 other leaders had hoped their summit would celebrate fresh unity against Russia's Vladimir Putin, send a warning to China and prove the alliance is as strong as ever in its 75th year, but the three days of pageantry will be overshadowed by domestic turmoil across the alliance.

item.title: Energy Tax Credit Fight Splits GOP in Snag for Speaker
item.description: Moderate House Republicans are lobbying House Speaker Mike Johnson to lessen cuts to several clean energy tax credits in the broad tax and spending bill prior to the GOP’s plans to bring it to the floor next week.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: Jen Kiggans

item.title: Trump’s Aerospace Deals Were Big on Numbers and Slim on Details
item.description: US President Donald Trump ended his tour of the Middle East’s wealthiest countries touting new investments totaling a claimed $3.6 trillion — though upon closer inspection many of the deals appear inflated or recycled.
item.dc:creator: Leen Al-Rashdan

media:content.media:description: Boeing CEO Kelly Ortberg sits to the left of US President Donal Trump and Qatar's Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad al-Thani (R) during a business deal signing ceremony at the Royal Palace in Doha, on May 14, 2025. Trump touched down at Hamad International Airport in Doha, with relations between the two governments in the spotlight over Qatar's offer to Trump of a $400 million luxury aircraft to serve as a new Air Force One and then pass into his personal use. (Photo by Brendan SMIALOWSKI / AFP) (Photo by BRENDAN SMIALOWSKI/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Gulf States Embrace Trump’s New Vision of Middle East
item.description: At every stop on his just-ended tour, President Donald Trump’s words were music to the ears of his Saudi, Qatari and Emirati hosts.
item.dc:creator: Sam Dagher

media:content.media:description: Attendees wait to hear MBS and President Trump speak during a Saudi-US investment forum on May 13. Photographer: Brendan Smialowski/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Ex-US Envoy to Ukraine Says She Resigned to Protest Trump Policy
item.description: The former US ambassador to Ukraine said she resigned in protest over President Donald Trump’s handling of the conflict with Russia and that she could no longer stand by while he pressured the government in Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Nick Wadhams

media:content.media:description: Bridget Brink Photographer: SAUL LOEB/AFP

item.title: Trump Berates Republicans to ‘Stop Talking,’ Pass Tax Cuts
item.description: President Donald Trump called on members of his party to unite behind his economic agenda in Congress, putting pressure on factions of lawmakers who are calling for last-minute changes to the legislation to drop their demands.
item.dc:creator: Emily Birnbaum, Tyler Kendall

media:content.media:description: ABU DHABI, UNITED ARAB EMIRATES - MAY 16: U.S. President Donald J. Trump speaks to media on Air Force One as he departs the Al Bateen Executive Airport on May 15, 2025, in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates. Trump is on the fourth and final day of his visit to the Gulf to underscore the strategic partnership between the United States and regional allies including the UAE, focusing on security and economic collaboration. (Photo by Win McNamee/Getty Images)

item.title: Russia, Ukraine Discussed Truce, Prisoner Swap at Direct Talks
item.description: The first direct talks between Russia and Ukraine in more than three years ended in Turkey with an agreement on an exchange of prisoners and discussions on a potential ceasefire, though no truce was announced.
item.dc:creator: Daryna Krasnolutska, Natalia Drozdiak, Selcan Hacaoglu

media:content.media:description: Hakan Fidan chairs a meeting with Russia and Ukraine at Dolmabahce Palace in Istanbul, on May 16.

item.title: Petro Shrugs Off US Move to Defund Chinese Projects in Colombia
item.description: President Gustavo Petro brushed off the US bid to block the financing of projects in Colombia being built by Chinese state companies as his administration moved to join a development bank backed by the Asian nation.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Medina, Andrea Jaramillo

media:content.media:description: A construction crew works on pillars for the Bogotá metro project Colombia’s capital in July 2024.

item.title: EU Prepares Sanctions on Third-Party Banks Supporting Russia
item.description: The European Union is working on a new sanctions package that will target the Russian financial sector in the latest effort by Ukraine’s allies to place pressure on President Vladimir Putin to negotiate a peace deal to end the war.
item.dc:creator: Michal Kubala, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: The Moscow International Business Center beond the Kremlin.

item.title: Trump’s Cuts at Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac May Slow Housing Recovery, Report Says
item.description: The Trump administration’s cuts to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-sponsored mortgage giants, may put a damper on the housing market as it becomes harder to obtain some types of home loans, according to a report from Bloomberg Intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Scott Carpenter

item.title: Can Trump Really End Birthright Citizenship?
item.description: President Donald Trump is fighting to end automatic citizenship for children born to parents who are in the country unlawfully or on temporary visas, part of his broader crackdown on immigration and a change that would overturn more than a century of court precedent.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson

media:content.media:description: Legal and legislative challenges to birthright citizenship have, like Trump’s order, often rested on the argument that the children of undocumented immigrants aren’t “subject to the jurisdiction” of the US.

item.title: Tusk Ally Slides in Polls Before Polish Presidential Ballot
item.description: Support for Warsaw Mayor Rafal Trzaskowski declined in the latest opinion surveys before Poland’s presidential election on Sunday, signaling a closer race with the populist opposition and weakening stocks and the zloty.
item.dc:creator: Wojciech Moskwa

media:content.media:description: A supporter of Rafal Trzaskowski, mayor of Warsaw and presidential candidate, during a campaign rally in Brzeg, Poland, on Wednesday, May 14, 2025. Poland's presidential election is scheduled for May 18, a run-off between the top two candidates will take place two weeks later if nobody wins at least 50% of the vote in the first round.

item.title: Zelenskiy, European Leaders Speak With Trump by Phone
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy, French President Emmanuel Macron, UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer, German Chancellor Friedrich Merz and Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk spoke with US President Donald Trump on the phone, Zelenskiy’s spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: Deana Kjuka, Kateryna Chursina

media:content.media:description: Volodymyr Zelenskiy takes part in a meeting during the European Political Community summit, in Tirana on May 16.

item.title: Trump Attacks South Africa Again Before Ramaphosa Visit
item.description: US President Donald Trump for the second time in a week accused South Africa of perpetrating a genocide against White people — without any proof — just days before he is set to receive the country’s leader, Cyril Ramaphosa, in the White House.
item.dc:creator: Jordan Fabian, Neil Munshi

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump speaks to members of media on Air Force One on May 15.

item.title: Abu Dhabi’s ‘Man in Manhattan’ Is Key to Unlocking Trump Deals
item.description: In a power circle dominated by Abu Dhabi’s ruling family, Marty Edelman stands out as a rare outsider with real influence.
item.dc:creator: Ben Bartenstein, Dinesh Nair, Alex Dooler

media:content.media:description: Martin Edelman at Yankee Stadium in New York in July 2024.

item.title: Trump Says US to Set Tariff Rates for Other Nations in Weeks
item.description: President Donald Trump said he would set tariff rates for US trading partners “over the next two to three weeks,” saying his administration lacks the capacity to negotiate deals with all of its trading partners.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, alongside Scott Bessent, left, and Howard Lutnick at the White House in February.

item.title: Trump Says Iran Has US Nuclear Proposal, Must ‘Move Quickly’
item.description: President Donald Trump said the US had presented Iran with a proposal over Tehran’s nuclear ambitions and that the country’s negotiators needed to move soon on the offer as talks intensify.
item.dc:creator: Kate Sullivan, Patrick Sykes

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump speaks to media on Air Force One as he departs Abu Dhabi on May 15.

item.title: EU Economy Chief Urges China Self-Restraint on Diverting Goods
item.description: The European Union’s economy chief urged China to avoid flooding the European market with its goods as it seeks to avoid US tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Kriti Gupta

media:content.media:description: Valdis Dombrovskis, trade commissioner for the European Union (EU), during a news conference following the Economic and Financial Affairs Council (ECOFIN) meeting at the European Council headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, on Tuesday, May 13, 2025. A top European Union policymaker said the region should take advantage of investor doubts in the dollar and US Treasuries.

item.title: Russia, Ukraine, Turkey Delegations Hold Meeting in Istanbul
item.description: Talks between delegations of Ukraine, Russia and Turkey started in Istanbul, according to live broadcast on Turkish TV channel TRT.
item.dc:creator: Aliaksandr Kudrytski, Taylan Bilgic, Daryna Krasnolutska

media:content.media:description: Firefighters inspect the damage to a residential building following a Russian night drone strike in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Sunday, March 23, 2025. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy agreed to a proposal for a mutual halt to strikes on energy assets as an initial step in President Donald Trump’s effort to end the war that began with Russia’s full-scale invasion three years ago. Photographer: Andrew Kravchenko/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Wants Putin Meeting ‘Soon,’ Heads Home From Mideast
item.description: President Donald Trump said he would meet Russian President Vladimir Putin “as soon as we can set it up,” foreclosing an immediate face-to-face encounter aimed at brokering an end to the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump, center, speaks during the US-UAE Investment Forum in Abu Dhabi on May 16. Photographer: Brendan Smialowski/Getty Images

item.title: Israel Alarmed by Trump’s Arms Sales and Deals With Gulf States
item.description: President Donald Trump’s Middle East tour has left Israel apprehensive about a shift in US foreign policy from one rooted in security to a focus on commerce, especially massive arms sales to neighbors that don’t recognize the Jewish state.
item.dc:creator: Galit Altstein, Ethan Bronner

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump reviews the honour guard at the Royal Court in Riyadh on May 13.

item.title: APEC Trade Ministers Agree Statement Without Mentioning Tariffs
item.description: Trade chiefs from some of the world’s biggest economies including the US and China agreed to focus on reforming global trade rules, after reaching an unexpected agreement by ignoring one of their biggest points of difference: tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara, Soo-Hyang Choi, James Mayger

media:content.media:description: The Taicang Port Area International Container Terminal in Suzhou, China.

item.title: Treasuries, US-Made Japanese Cars Seen as Leverage
item.description: Holding longer-term Treasuries and importing Japanese cars manufactured in the US are among the possible bargaining chips for Tokyo in its talks with Washington over President Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs, according to the leader of a small but influential opposition party.
item.dc:creator: Akemi Terukina, Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Traffic travels along a road as pedestrians using umbrellas walk along sidewalks in Tokyo, Japan, on Wednesday, April 1, 2020. Japan’s coronavirus numbers have been ticking up, sparking alarm that it could be the next major country to see an explosive jump in infections. It’s also raising questions about whether Tokyo is about to go into a European-style lockdown -- speculation the government is trying to squash. Photographer: Noriko Hayashi/Bloomberg

item.title: Gold Palaces, Jet Deals and McDonald’s: Trump at Home in Middle East
item.description: Donald Trump beamed from the passenger seat of a golf cart as Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman took the wheel and personally whisked the US president to a desert oasis dinner in an ancient city.
item.dc:creator: Kate Sullivan

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman during a signing ceremony at the Royal Palace, Saudi Arabia.

item.title: US Patience Running Thin on Ukraine Peace Bid
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Halpin

media:content.media:description: A meeting of Turkish, US and Ukrainian officials in Istanbul, on May 16. Photographer: Murat Gok/Anadolu/Getty Images

item.title: Trump’s Rush to Cut AI Deals in Saudi Arabia and UAE Opens Rift With China Hawks
item.description: President Donald Trump’s flurry of artificial intelligence deals during his tour of the Middle East is opening a rift within his own administration as China hawks grow increasingly concerned the projects are putting US national security and economic interests at risk.
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie Hawkins, Jenny Leonard

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman arrive at the Gulf Cooperation Council Leaders’ Summit in Riyadh on May 14.

item.title: Ukraine Truce Prospects Dim as Calls for New Sanctions Grow
item.description: Hopes faded for a Ukraine ceasefire after President Vladimir Putin sent a low-level delegation to talks in Turkey, while attention shifted to bids on Capitol Hill for fresh sanctions to bring the Russian leader to the negotiating table.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Drozdiak, Jamie Tarabay

media:content.media:description: Ukraine’s Andrii Sybiha, left, Lindsey Graham and Marco Rubio in Antalya, on May 15.
